EDUCATION POLICY
(White Paper)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question - [5th April]:

    That this House approves the adoption of the Education Policy outlined in the White

Column: 1900

Paper on Education Policy as contained in Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 15 of 1956. - (The Minister for Education.)

    Question again proposed.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is much to commend in the broad principles laid down in the White Paper: for example, that all schools should receive equal treatment and that all regulations should apply equally to all schools which are financed or aided by Government; that teachers with the same or equivalent qualifications and experience should be paid the same salary; and that every parent should have the right of choice regarding the first and second languages which his children should learn. These principles will be acceptable to the majority. But when we begin to examine the White Paper to see how some of these principles are to be carried out in practice, we find that the Government skates somewhat uncomfortably over the problem. This White Paper, in fact, is the work of politicians rather than of educationists.

    The main problem, of course, is that of language. The All-Party Committee plunged into trouble when they recommended in Section I:

    "That at least two of the following languages, English, Malay, Mandarin and Tamil should be the media of instruction in their respective schools."

    If you are to take that statement literally, it would mean that students should be taught all the subjects in the curriculum in one language and then all over again in the second language. That, I presume, is not what the Committee meant, but that is what they said, and they then tried to extricate themselves from the difficulty by recommending bilingual teachers so that instruction in certain subjects could be switched from one language to another, the students having equal facility in the two languages concerned, presumably, in the main, English and Mandarin. The White Paper skates over the impracticability of this politicians' solution to all our ills, merely stating that there must be a primary followed by a secondary language of the parents' choice, and that students must be able

Column: 1901

to leave the primary school with a competent knowledge of one language and a fair working knowledge in the second language. The implication is that if you Malayanise the textbooks and prune the syllabuses of all non-essentials, whatever that may mean, this can be accomplished. But what happens after that? Are two languages to be taught almost side by side in the secondary schools, technical schools and so on? The White Paper, for very good reasons, remains silent on this point.

    Sir, let us get down to what can and what cannot be done in our schools - educationally, I mean, and not politically. Firstly, it may be possible, up to a certain point, to give instruction in two languages in the primary stage, but the shortened hours of work, due to the doubling of morning and afternoon schools, is a terrible handicap. But when you reach the secondary stage, there can only be one medium of instruction if the most important part of a student's life is going to be properly utilised in turning him from a comparatively ignorant lad of 12 or thereabouts into a maturing young man of 16 to 17. There is so much to be crammed into those four years that there must already have been planted in him one language in which he thinks and writes and speaks without hesitation; and this language must be the one through which he will imbibe all that he must learn in his secondary school life. By all means let him have a second language, learn it properly as a subject and pass examinations in it, but it is out of the question to allow it to be used as a second medium of instruction at this stage of his education. It just will not work and the Government, I feel, has not adequately faced up to this fact.

    This brings mc to the question of the Malayanisation of textbooks. The Government has accepted the recommendation of the All-Party Committee lock, stock and barrel, but there can be no question that syllabuses and textbooks must be Malayanised as quickly as possible. Here again, we get into considerable trouble and it is not at all

Column: 1902

clear whether the All-Party Committee accepts or rejects the recommendations of the Chinese educational authorities in paragraph 55 of their report, although these get to the core of the whole matter. It reads as follows:

    "They (that is, the representatives of Chinese educational bodies) make one reservation, however, in that in Chinese Literature as a subject, they advocate no serious deletions as the Chinese classics are in most cases, if not in fact, in all, crystallisations of Chinese culture, and if these are banned Chinese culture will suffer. They claim that these classics also offer the very much needed balance in Malayan Chinese education, which must retain in it anything that encouraged moral values and concepts, and strive to produce an all-round citizen. To cut out Confucius or Mencius from Chinese Literature is as unthinkable as to omit Shakespeare or Milton from a study of English Literature."

    While it is not clear whether the All-Party Committee, as I say, accepts or rejects this point of view, the Government seems to ignore this point altogether. But let us remember now that, with the possible exception of Malay, all the other three languages have been nurtured and developed in the countries of their origin. Consequently, the classics and all other good standard textbooks in these languages must naturally be imbued with the history and the splendour and the innate qualities of those countries. How then can the Committee Malayanise such textbooks? No one in his sane moments will suggest that there are persons in Malaya capable of producing Malayanised textbooks in the three languages comparable to the thoughts and the beauty and the grandeur of Confucius or Mencius, Shakespeare or Milton. There have been no great Malayan philosophers and no great Malayan poets to make this possible. Even my hon. Friend, Mr R. C. H. Lim, would not aspire that high! Now the very fact that Government has as its policy that there should be equal respect for the four principal cultures of Singapore is an admission that Malayanisation of textbooks is an impossibility.

    What we presume the Government means, and what the All-Party Committee ought to mean, is that for many years to come all that we can hope for is to produce Malayanised textbooks

Column: 1903

in three languages for the lowest classes, perhaps for the primary schools. The Pan-Malayan Text-Book Committee, to which the White Paper refers in paragraph 19, was intended surely only to produce textbooks for the primary classes. I fully agree that simple readers for young students should have a Malayan background. I agree that our children should learn about tembusus rather than oaks, but I will not support the view that Keats' Ode to a Nightingale should be Malayanised just because there are no nightingales in this country. Malayanise your teachers by all means, so that they can interpret the wide world in a Malayan way, for it is the teaching that matters far more than the textbooks.

    If, as the All-Party Committee stated, language teaching should be of the best possible standards, then we must perforce teach through the media of the classics from the countries whence the languages originated. Both the Government and the Committee have tried to duck this simple fact, and the more one tries to ignore it, the more the educational system of this country will tie itself in knots. I admit freely that it is a dilemma. I am second to none in my belief that the people of this country can only come together as Malayans by sharing each other's languages and cultures, but it must be recognised that equal facility in three languages, or even two languages, does not come at the primary or secondary stage of education, with which we are most concerned in this debate. We must accept the fact that we must aim at the mastery of one language which the parent chooses, and a sufficient grounding in the second language for it to be easily studied and mastered at the university or later stage, while a third language - alas, I think - must be left as an optional extra curricular activity for which facilities will have to be made available.

    Before I leave this aspect of the White Paper, may I have your permission, Sir, to read a short paragraph from a recent article on the problems of education facing the Central Advisory Council for Education in Britain, where there is, of

Column: 1904

course, only one language as the medium of instruction:

    "Undoubtedly, however, the real centre of difficulty and dispute lies in the curriculum of the Sixth Forms of Grammar schools. The trouble is well-known. Universities find many of their scientific entrants narrow in mind and unable to write or even speak plain English. The Arts specialists, on the other hand, may be able to write a properly argued and punctuated essay (though this cannot be taken for granted), but he is totally ignorant of science and of the changed view of the world that is brought about. They are, furthermore, products almost exclusively limited to England and Wales in the modern world. No other system of education anywhere permits too early this sharp and harmful division between the Arts and the Sciences. The dangers of over-specialisation might seem so obvious that its removal would be simple. Unhappily, a radical attack on it would shake higher education to its foundations. It would certainly mean lower standards of attainment in the main subjects in university entrance and open scholarships. It might end by adding a year to university courses. The tangle largely defeated a Committee of Vice-Chancellors and school heads which reported last summer."

If that, Sir, is the problem in England where only one language is concerned, how much more intricate is our problem here. In this country we are crying out for our local sons and daughters with qualifications for all kinds of technical and administrative posts. Are we going to get them if we make them over-concentrate on languages and limit their outlook by giving them Malayanised textbooks, and are we not therefore indulging in contradictions?

    I must now turn more briefly to other aspects of the White Paper. I welcome the introduction of Civics as an essential subject, but I would prefer to call it Citizenship which, I think, conveys better the spirit of what is intended. Civics implies abstract book knowledge, while Citizenship suggests the living world around us, an object of wonder to both teacher and taught. Because the teacher should teach, not as one conveying truths which are absolute but as one imparting information which may be questioned. Small children are by nature inquisitive and sceptical. The effect of much teaching is too often to overlay these original impulses and to convert the inquisitive questioning child into the passive recipient of information. This is particularly unfortunate if citizens are to be educated. After all,

Column: 1905

had we all been brought up never to believe what the newspapers say, much less politicians, the world would be a happier place. And so let us talk of Citizenship, not Civics, and let us make certain that our teachers are good citizens too, in the sense that they are still ready to learn as well as to teach.

    I welcome also paragraph 24 of the White Paper which refers to competition in sports between different schools, but this should be expanded to include Art and Music. In this connection, I think that the House would be interested to know that, by arrangement with the Singapore Musical Society, two celebrated international artists - a violinist and a pianist - are giving a concert tomorrow in the hall of the Chinese High School, thanks to the enthusiasm of the Principal of that school. So far as I know, this is the first time that such an event is taking place, and it is a happy indication that the Chinese High School is not exclusively concerned with Chinese culture. It is admittedly an experiment, but I believe it to be an important one, and the Principal is confident that a large number of his students will attend the concert, sandwiched as it is between the morning and afternoon classes.

    While on this subject, I would like the Minister to know that this interest in Western music - and there is an interest - among the Chinese schools is not being sufficiently encouraged by the Ministry of Education. The Singapore Musical Society, of which I happen to be Chairman, holds regular concerts for schools when celebrated musicians visit us. Notices are sent out regularly by the Ministry to Government schools and English aided schools, but not always Chinese schools. This is one instance of how a great gulf can be fixed between Chinese schools and Government schools, and I would ask the Minister to make sure that there is no discrimination in the field of music in future.

    There are two or three other matters on which I must touch briefly. Firstly, I deplore the fact that the Government has no adequate plans for those students to remain in school who failed to qualify for secondary education. Are we to push out on to the streets at least half

Column: 1906

of our rapidly increasing 14-year olds at an age when jobs are almost impossible to obtain? Of such are Communists and gangsters made. That the Government does not seem to be willing to tackle this matter seriously can be seen from paragraph 40, where it is stated of last year's students:

    "Of the 45 per cent who failed to find places in Government secondary schools, those under 14« were allowed to remain in their primary schools, and instruction is being provided in evening classes for those of the remainder who are interested."

    This implies that the Government is not sufficiently interested in seeing that this class of students is properly catered for and this is a deplorable confession. Half of the 14 to 15 year olds are to be abandoned to their devices unless they happen to be interested in evening classes. This will not do. The Minister must know perfectly well that students who have left school at the end of the primary school stage are virtually unemployable, and that they must be given courses of instruction to equip them to become junior clerks or apprentices in industry or fit for the national defence forces. If Government is not interested in these young people at this very formative age, it will be failing in its duty. This is the most lamentable gap in the whole White Paper and we shall not be satisfied unless a solution is found to a very serious problem.

    Secondly, the next paragraph, No. 41, refers to the need to retain those teachers, now in the service, to cope with the expanding secondary education in 1960, but this principle, Sir, should be extended to all types of schools. It seems to me pure folly to retire teachers at the age of 55 when the crying need is for more and more teachers. At a time when the average age of teachers in the school is dropping considerably, a levelling of the experience of the older men would have a beneficial and steadying influence. At my own school I well remember that house-masters had to retire at the age of 60 and teachers at the age of 55, which meant that house-masters at the age of 60 could revert to teaching for another five years as very valued and experienced men. I see no

Column: 1907

reason why the same sort of thing could not happen here - set the age limit of principals at 60, but allow teachers to go on to the age of 65; principals to be re-engaged on a supernumerary basis as teachers for five years, thus stepping aside for the younger men to do the more strenuous administrative work. Many teachers retiring at the age of 55 today turn to other forms of employment in order to supplement their small pensions. Most of them would be much happier and much more useful continuing to teach the young, but in positions of less responsibility. I hope that the Minister will consider this suggestion in all seriousness.

    I must also issue a word of warning regarding condition (vi) of paragraph 26 which the school must fulfil in order to qualify for Government aid:

    "The general education policy of the school must not in any way conflict with the education policy laid down by the Government."

    As it stands, this clause means, or I hope it means, not that there should be 100 per cent uniformity in schools but that there should be uniformity in essentials and diversity in non-essentials. The danger can be that the State-controlled institutions will have their own initiative reduced by conforming to one rigid model which is not in the true interests of education. There cannot be, particularly in a multi-racial country, one perfect model system or one perfect model method for all schools. In other words, while the idea that all regulations should apply to all schools is good in principle, there must be freedom for the principal of a school or a committee of management to evolve its own methods and make its own experiment in the educational field. We do not want the dull dead hand of the State to kill initiative and enterprise among teachers, for that is the very thing which education must encourage and develop. To put it another way, we ought to create great headmasters and great principals and not great registrars. These are the main points on which I want to touch regarding the contents of the White Paper.

    I must now refer to two significant omissions. We read nothing in the White Paper and we have heard nothing

Column: 1908

in the Minister's speech which would indicate, on the one hand, what the new education plan is going to cost, and, on the other hand, in what stages and over how long a period of years it is proposed to implement it. It is all very well to get the scheme on paper and be as proud of it as my hon. Friend the Chief Minister says he is, but he will be the first to acknowledge that the more important thing is to indicate to the House when and how the Government proposes to implement it. It is on this very point that we have our doubts, because Government performances in the field of education have not been on a par with their promises.

    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): When?

    Mr John Ede: In the often quoted pamphlet -

    The Chief Minister: When?

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr John Ede: In the often quoted pamphlet of the Labour Front, it was stated that the policy was "free compulsory schooling for all children, - "

    The Chief Minister: For four years.

    Mr John Ede: " - in English or vernacular schools, for the first six years as a matter of first priority." As my hon. Friend interrupts, that was understandably to be a policy for four years, and the policy of the first year, as given in the Governor's speech, was a six-year course of free primary education for all children. Now, not the slightest attempt has been made to implement this policy. For several months I have pressed the Government to disclose its plans to build more cheaply constructed schools which alone could make this policy effective. Only a week ago I got this answer from the Minister - "All new plans need time to work out" - and the statement that sites have been found for school buildings - only sites. If this is all that the Government can show for their first year in office, is it surprising that we have misgivings as to how soon and how vigorously the implementation of the White Paper is going to be tackled? I hope that we shall hear of a definite time-table of action from the Minister

Column: 1909

when he winds up this debate and a definite statement of the financial implications. Despite our misgivings, it is not our purpose to oppose the motion that is before us today but to support it, for, as I have said, the broad principles laid down are generally satisfactory; but we shall have reason to oppose the Education Bill when it is introduced later on in this House if the points I have raised have not been taken into consideration.

    In conclusion, therefore, this White Paper is a step forward towards an improved educational system for this country. I have indicated some of the weaknesses which do not, however, spoil the broad pattern of what has been conceived. But let me say this. One of the main problems and fears has been how to fit the Chinese schools into this pattern. But I am inclined to believe that, whatever objections remain in the minds of Chinese educationists, once they are brought under one system, these will evaporate in an independent Singapore, because, in an independent Singapore, it stands to reason that all schools - whether Chinese, Malay, Tamil or English - will and must be of equal status and equal importance. There will be no longer any room for the feeling that Chinese or Malay or Tamil schools are being ignored, for how could they be ignored in an independent Singapore and by a freely elected government?

    The teaching profession is the most hard-working and self-sacrificing profession of all, often misunderstood and almost always under-paid; but let us not suppose that because so often under-paid, such teachers are necessarily poor in quality, as the White Paper rather unfairly seems to suggest. There are many teachers - and it applies everywhere, not only to Singapore - who work for the sheer love of teaching. All the more power to them! I feel confident that in the Singapore of the future the teachers will continue to be true to their great traditions and that they will rise to their very noble responsibilities of producing loyal young citizens in their thousands who are able and willing to maintain and protect their nation's independence.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, it would have been optimistic for anybody to expect that

Column: 1910

there will be no criticism on a vital matter like the education policy of the Government of Singapore. Indeed, it would have been optimistic for us to have expected that even the All-Party Report on Chinese Education would have met with approval from all sections of the community. This is a thorny subject. I have used the word "primordial" once and it brought a rebuke from the hon. Mr Sutherland, but that was, perhaps, because he does not understand these things.

    Talk of policy in education and you touch upon the very heartstrings of the three main cultural groups in Malaya. You bring forth all the inherent conflicts, the urge for supremacy and dominance of each culture and each group.

    There are four topics in the All-Party Report on Chinese Education which we knew would arouse the fiercest controversy. They were: first, those statutes empowering the Government to cancel the registration of schools and to close them down; second, grants-in-aid, with conditions; third, Malayanisation of textbooks; and, fourth, languages to be taught other than the mother tongue.

    Sir, for the last 50 years the Chinese schools have grown progressively more and more suspicious and more and more hostile of the Government. It is important to remember that, as far as they are concerned, they do not see any difference between a colonial Government and one under the Rendel Constitution. It may be an unfair thing to those legal experts who can point out the differences between what the colonial Government was and what it is now. Nevertheless, as far as Chinese educational authorities, the school committees, the Chambers of Commerce, the clan associations are concerned, there has been no real or significant change. It is unrealistic on our part to hope that they would accept these Ordinances when they are administered by representatives of a new Rendel government when they had resisted them when they were administered by colonial officials. The only conclusion that the All-Party Committee

Column: 1911

came to is that it is impossible to allow a state of affairs where a government, soon to be a completely elected one, is not in complete control of the educational system. So we recommended that all those statutes, which were at the time they were drafted designed to meet problems in the Chinese schools and were drafted specially to apply to them, should be amended. Sir, we have to accept the fact that for the time being there will be resistance from certain communal quarters to Government control over management and registration of schools. At the same time even they will not ultimately be able to resist the proposition that there must be one authority in a country, and that authority is the government of that country through its popularly elected representatives.

    The second matter which I expected would raise new controversy was grants-in-aid. Here again I think the biggest stroke of bad statesmanship, if statesmanship was what it was intended to be, was the offer of $12 millions to Chinese schools at the height of the anti-national service campaign. Sir, I do not know who advised His Excellency the Governor in those days. I understand that there was an Executive Council which included elected Members like the then hon. Mr C. C. Tan and his friends. They did not understand what was happening in Malaya, and not understanding it, they were unable to find the right solution. To offer a bribe of $12 millions to school committees and school teachers to place the whole school administrative machinery under Government control was the stupidest thing that they could have done. It completely soured the whole outlook of the Chinese schools, the management committees, the clan associations, the Parent-Teachers Association and the whole host of other interested and active bodies. Here again, it is unrealistic of us to expect that resistance, which has been built up over the years through genuine frustrations and grievances, would be washed away just because there are now nine popularly elected Ministers, I beg your pardon, five popularly elected Members, and one nominated Member and three officials.

Column: 1912



    The Chief Minister: Six.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Six? I beg your pardon, Mr Speaker, Sir. I cannot catch up with the number of Ministers and Junior Ministers in this House!

    The Chief Minister: You want to wake up!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: The only proposition one can honestly support is that if a government is to expend public money on any educational system it must have some say on how that educational system is going to be run. However, I do see that there may be objections to certain conditions in the White Paper. I feel that the fourth condition in paragraph 26:

    "No principal or teacher shall be appointed or dismissed without the approval of the Registrar;"

has got all the inherent dangers of brainwashing and thought control through the teaching staff. Sir, we must understand the attitude with which this problem will be approached by the communities which are not adequately represented in this House. If we do not take the trouble to understand it, then we are likely to make as much a mess of it as the former hon. Member Mr C. C. Tan.

    We support the principle that no government can give away $12 millions or $50 millions to private groups of persons to run private institutions. But we do appreciate that, in the situation as it exists in Singapore, taking into account the historical background of the schools, there should be discussions and negotiations over these conditions. There should be fair and just conditions to ensure that the government has an effective say in the education policy. But they should not be conditions which would make for tyranny in the hands of either the Registrar or the Permanent Secretary in the Education Ministry. It is only on account of this that we thought there was some reason for the request for a postponement of the debate on this motion. But the Chief Minister has stated that he suspects that there are other motives behind the request for the postponement and he has insisted that the debate goes on today.

Column: 1913



    The next thorny subject is Malayanisation. Sir, this has got nothing to do with expatriates, getting rid of them, giving them a handsome bonus and pushing them off in the first ship. We do not propose to score out any Nightingales, nor do we wish to cut out the wise sayings of Confucius and Mencius. When we in the All-Party Committee on Chinese Education recommended that there should be Malayanisation of textbooks, our idea was simple. The whole political emphasis - and education is the only means by which you can do it - must be on the reorientation of one's heart, one's loyalties to this new Malaya. We expected a great deal of opposition to this because it would straightaway rouse the bogey of culture being endangered. There was a good reason for that bogey in the old days when the Governor thought that he knew what was good for the people of Singapore.

    Sir, we can fairly put it this way. Nothing that anybody can do in or outside Malaya will alter the fact that there will be two dominant languages and cultures in Malaya. These are the facts in our population figures. The Malay language and the Malay culture will irresistibly become the predominant language and the predominant culture. The Chinese language and the Chinese culture, particularly in view of the tremendous renascence that it has undergone in China, will occupy a very important place in Malaya. Perhaps it is because my hon. Friend the Member for Tanglin (Mr Ede) is not as acutely conscious of these facts, as an Asian is, that his excellent speech on the technique of education was somewhat lacking in its grasp of the more deep-seated problems that we face. Sir, the Chinese culture as it will be in the Malaya of 200 years from now is not likely to be what Chinese culture will be 200 years from now in China. That is inevitable. We need not score out Confucius and Mencius.

    Nobody denies that it was the British who first colonised America, and that they speak the English language. But he would be a bold man indeed to say that in America they have the same identical language and the same identi-

Column: 1914

cal culture. In fact, you cannot think of a more supreme insult to an Englishman than to mistake him for an American!

    Mr Sutherland (Nominated): No!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Indeed this one culture and one language spread over five continents - New Zealand, Australia, South Africa - has gone through mutations. Basically it is the same language and the same Anglo-Saxon culture.
